Students will take a quiz and exams covering the content of the course, complete short writing assignments, and actively participate during lecture (using student response system technology).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Fundamentals of neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, and neuroscientific methods. Brain processes related to sensory processing, motor control, plasticity, and memory. Students will take a quiz and exams covering the content of the course, complete short writing assignments, and actively participate during lecture (using student response system technology).

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Prerequisite: PSCH 110
A prior course in biology is strongly recommended, but not required.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. appreciate the field of neuroscience and its historical foundations
2. identify the structures of the nervous system, especially the brain, and characterize their function (functional neuroanatomy)
3. outline the anatomy of neurons and explain their physiology
4. describe the methods of cognitive and behavioral neuroscience research
5. summarize the chemistry of the nervous system and explain the effects of various psychoactive drugs
6. describe the processes that occur during development of the nervous system
7. explain the brain processes related to sensory processing, motor control, neural plasticity, and memory
8. explain the biological basis of various neurological conditions, psychiatric disorders, and mental illnesses
9. determine the location and cause of brain damage or neuropathology, given the impaired and preserved abilities of a neurological patient, and vice versa
10. read, understand, and critically evaluate research about brain and behavior as reported in both the popular media and in academic journals
11. discuss the contribution of various brain processes to everyday behavior

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Case studies: Discussion of classic neuropsychology case studies
Class participation: Clicker questions integrated into lecture
Films / videos: Case studies often include video footage
Lecture: Two 80-minute lectures weekly
Online work: Online quiz and discussion/comments
Readings: Textbook and supplementary readings (posted online)
Writing assignments: Several short, informal writing assignments

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Class participation: Low-stakes clicker questions integrated into lecture
Exam, final: During finals week
Exam, mid-term: One midterm exam
Quizzes: Administered online
Writing assignments: Several short writing assignments

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Breedlove, S. M., & Watson, N. V. (2013). Biological psychology: An introduction to behavioral, cognitive, and clinical neuroscience (7th ed.). Sunderland, MA: Sinauer Associates. ISBN: 978-0-87893-927-5 (hardcover), 978-1-60535-170-4 (looseleaf).
